Posts.Title: Question about hair growth

Posts.Content: Hi Gaynor123, I'm due to have my 2nd FEC cocktail on Tuesday, and like you, after my first I was waiting for side effects to kick in - but they never did.  I was so lucky, just a wobbly tummy and a woolly brain for a couple of days.  But I got over ambitious and felt so good on the Friday I decided to clean the house from top to bottom - ended up in A&E feeling so poorly.  The moral of that tale, for me, is that even though you feel fine your body is still fighting a battle with all the drugs and you really can't do everything you used to at the same pace.  Take it easy, don't hibernate, but respect the hard work your body is doing in the background!  Im not as worried as I thought I'd be about my 2nd but I do realise that the side effects may be cumulative and I might not get off so lightly next time. I guess what I'm trying to say is just what lots of others have said before, we're all different but if you don't have a hard time just be glad and take the opportunity to rest and look after yourself. Much love xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Lizy, Welcome to the roller coaster! As all the ladies have already said, this experience is different for all of us but one thing that is certain, we will all get through it and remember always you're not on your own. I was diagnosed with bc in July last year (2015!) and had a lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy.  I had lots of test and scans including the oncotype dx and was advised to have chemotherapy.  I am on the FEC-T cocktail and feel really lucky that the side effects of FEC weren't too bad at all.  I know some ladies have been really sickly but you are given anti-sickness tablets - do take them if you need to.  The most important thing to remember is that it passes - it's rubbish while you feel rough but it does pass.  Rest as much as you need to - there's no such thing as too much rest if you're tired.  It's true that the T part of the chemo is much more aggressive and the side effects can be pretty nasty.  I had a bad time on my first T cycle, as well as SE I managed to pick up an infection and ended up in A&E, but they were great and after IV antibiotics and a fist full of more to take at home I was ok.  The pains that come with this chemo can be controlled to an extent with the painkillers but hot baths and hot water bottles are indispensable too.  Again, not everyone gets all or any of the SE so it's a case of wait and see.  After my first T I had an appointment with my oncologist and he lowered my dose by 15% (they can lower by as much as 20% and it's still classed as a full dose), the SE of my second T were not quite as bad as the first and certainly over quicker so it's worth bearing in mind that alterations can be made to your dose. Sorry this is an essay, but I want to share as much helpful info as I can.  As for your nails, I put the obligatory black nail polish on before I started T and so far have not had any problems - all still intact. Peeling skin on my hands has been kept under control with E45. Lastly, hair.  As so many other ladies have already said, it starts to fall out around 2 weeks after your first chemo. I had quite long hair but had it cut short before I even started chemo, thinking it would be less of a shock when I lost it all.  Before it started to drop I had a very sore head and after a couple of days it was hurting so much I just grabbed a razor and shaved it all off! What a relief, and it didn't look as bad a I thought it would - pleasant surprise.  I have a couple of wigs but some days just wear scarves. The Annabandana website has great scarves and bandanas at really good prices and I've seen quite a few ladies on here who recommend them. So, good luck, don't worry too much (I know that's easier said than done) it's a means to an end and before you know it you'll be looking back on all this as a memory.  I never thought it would come to an end but next Tuesday I have my sixth and last chemo which seems unbelievable now. Never forget this lovely community is always here to help. Love xxxxx

Posts.Title: Xmas

Posts.Content: Hi Jules, I was on Letrozole for 3 months and had to come off it due to aches and pains in my joints, particularly in my hands. I found it so hard to get up from bed, from a chair, anything, I was just so stiff and sore.   I've now been on Tamoxifen for about 2 weeks and things are a bit better.  The pains now seem to be nerve related rather than joints so I'm not so stiff in the mornings but I have a constant niggle, again especially in my hands, they seem to be my weakness. Personally I'm happier on tamoxifen but it's early days yet.  I've seen ladies on here who have had Letrozole and had no side effects at all, it's all very personal.  Although all these meds do basically the same thing and have very similar active ingredients, we are all very different and one person's reactions are not another's. Hope you find something that's suits you soon.  Xxxx

Posts.Title: Back from hospital after DIEP

Posts.Content: JJ, I joined this forum in September and you've been so supportive of me and lots of other ladies, with advice and words of wisdom, even sharing your own bad experiences with infections etc which in turn helped me to cope with mine.  I won't use the time honoured phrase 'you're strong' because that irritates me so much - we cope and we get through whatever this nasty critter throw at us because we have to. So, just think about all that you've gone through so far and where you are now - I bet there was a time you thought you'd never reach this point.  Well here you are with just an op to get through. I know 'just' is another irritating phrase but after what you've been through but after all that try to think of this as 'just' an op, whatever you feel like when you wake will pass in not too much time and then you'll look fab and can get on with your life!  Be scared, that's natural, but look forward to your life sailing and living.  Will be thinking of you tomorrow. Sending love xx
